journal-meta.journal-title: The Journal of Strain Analysis for Engineering Design

title-group.article-title: Analytical modelling of high-rate elasto-viscoplastic deformation of circular plates subjected to impulsive loads using pseudo-spectral collocation method

contrib-group.aff: Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Guilan, Rasht, Islamic Republic of Iran

author-notes.corresp: Asghar Zajkani, Department of Mechanical Engineering, Faculty of Engineering, University of Guilan, PO Box 3756, Rasht, Islamic Republic of Iran. Email: azajkani@gmail.com

abstract.p: An analytical methodology is developed to study dynamic elasto-viscoplastic behaviour of moderately thick circular plates subjected to high-intensity impulsive loads, comprehensively. First, incremental kinematic formulations are derived based on the first-order shear deformation theory to take into account viscous damping and rotary inertia. Geometrical and material non-linearities are applied by the complete von Kármán system and a mixed strain hardening law coupled with a physically based viscoplastic model, respectively. A semi-implicit scheme of return-mapping is employed by the cutting-plane algorithm to obtain effective plastic strains apart from satisfying the consistency condition. The subsequent part is devoted to the transformation of this boundary value problem into an initial value problem, to evaluate displacement fields. Spatial and temporal discretizations are carried out by the Chebyshev pseudo-spectral collocation method and Houbolt time-marching scheme, respectively. This transformation has been handled in the compact matrix forms to stabilize the solution and to make it more convenient. Influence of impulsive load and other parameters on plate deflections, effective strain and stress, temperature rise and stresses are considered. Ultimately, good accuracy is achieved through comparison between results and existing experimental data and finite element simulation from the literature. In addition, some challengeable aspects for the modelling are discussed.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Structural elements, especially plates, have extensive applications in the different frameworks, such as aeronautic apparatuses, ships, pressure vessels and other steel construction parts. For two reasons, determining the relationship between final deflections and intensity of impulsive loading is interesting for engineers. The first reason is to provide requirements for sheet metal forming applications as the substitutes for conventional industrial process. In this case, plastic instabilities would not be accrued. The second reason is to predict responses in dangerous situations and design secure structures for probable risks. In direct and inverse structural problems, modellings are developed depending on analysis efficiency to determine material and geometrical operative parameters in different loading sources. Reviewing literature, many substantial studies of plates subjected to various sources of impulsive loads can be found.1–11 Wen12 computed response of impulsively loaded circular plates by applying a simple power law representing work-hardening property. The Cowper–Symonds model has been frequently considered in diverse modellings (e.g. studies of Shen and Jones6 and Zaera et al.13). This model, as an empirical constitutive equation describes the effect of strain rate on the shock waved structure successfully. Jones and Oliveira14 and Li and Jones15 introduced three failure modes for circular plates, and then proposed an efficient criterion for dynamic plastic failure regarding transverse shear effects. As a different approach, Mihailescu-Suliciu and Wierzbicki16 calculated the transient responses by solving wave form equations in which discontinuity of the initial-boundary value problem was eliminated. On the other hand, many experimental results, which enable researchers to verify their simulations, have been provided.1,2,4,17–25 In addition, the finite element methods (FEMs) have been often implemented in some related works.3,8,22,26–29 Lee and Wierzbicki8,28 introduced three stages of deformation and fracture mechanisms where a thin plate was exposed under a localized pressure pulse. These stages were named as dishing, discing and petalling by two parts, parts I8 and II.28 For the dishing stage, several shape functions8 were applied to compare numerical results with analytical modelling, as in the study of Symonds and Wierzbicki10. They also investigated carefully several material models presented by others and quantified local strains. Moreover, effects of different pulse profiles in terms of time and spatial coordinates were studied. Defining an equivalent value for plastic strain, they could propose a ductile fracture criterion28 to predict other stages (discing and petalling) and propagations of circumferential and radial cracks. Balden and Nurick3 worked on deformation and post-failure behaviour using Abaqus. They investigated the characters of empirical data obtained from uniform distribution of blast loading as in the study by Teeling-Smith and Nurick.1 Bassia et al.26 studied the anomalous non-linear elastic–perfectly plastic behaviours of thin circular plates by the Galerkin methods and compared results with the Abaqus predictions. They argued about the unpredictability of the results and the extreme sensitivity to the parameters of dynamic responses of the plate, especially if the plate is modelled with more degrees of freedom. Stoffel et al.18 and Stoffel19,20 measured realistic deformation histories of metallic plates under pulse pressure inside a shock wave tube. They also obtained the worthy models for three metallic materials and compared FEM simulations versus several elasto-viscoplastic rules (i.e. Chaboche and Bodner–Partom). Alternately, unified strength theory (UST) was applied successfully to describe dynamic plastic behaviour of circular plates.30,31 Li and Jiang32 introduced an effective method to obtain the permanent deflection of underwater shock loaded plates. Recently, Amini et al.27 investigated numerically the high-rate behaviour of monolithic steel plates and bilayer (steel–polyurea) plates under high-intensity pressure pulses. They also paid attention to failure modes and compared results given by two types of FEM formulations with reverse ballistic experiments reported in the study by Amini et al.21 Bisadi and Meybodi22 considered simultaneous explosive forming–welding for two inhomogeneous plates, experimentally and numerically by finite element analysis. They also, used an equivalent homogeneous plate for bilayer metallic plates similar to composite beams. Using an energy method; they predicted the maximum deformation and possible rupture in plate analytically. Gharababaei and Darvizeh23–25 proposed simple analytical models to calculate midpoint deflection of thin circular plates under localized and uniform blast loading. In these analyses, a non-dimensional analysis with a singular value decomposition method,23 a simple effective upper bound solution24 and an energy approach25 has been presented using the rigid, perfectly plastic material model. They showed a minimum error in calculating the residual deflection of centre point, as compared to other existing models.

Consequently, many extensive attempts have been made to investigate the high-rate dynamic behaviour of plates. The analytical solutions in literature are mostly established on the simple constitutive equations of plasticity. However, some of the studies mentioned earlier (e.g. study by Gharababaei et al.25), despite being simple, illustrate satisfactory accuracies as compared to other models, but it should be pointed out that without utilizing some vital parameters, such as strain rates coming up from practical tests, these models are not able to predict the process perfectly. Therefore, compatibility between results naturally increases, particularly in the final stages.

In fact, there are relatively less comprehensive analytical solutions encompassing whole aspects of high-rate elasto-viscoplastic deflection, particularly for moderately thick circular plates, and these are challenging with complicated theories.
Therefore, we are primarily interested in contributing a comprehensive analytical modelling (strong form solution) solution, which follows the main specifications outlined below.

list-item.p: To enhance the efficiency of the solution, incremental formulation of governing and constitutive equations will be used corresponding to load increments. In fact, stepwise treatment can reduce the computational efforts meaningfully and determine responses uniquely (e.g. study by Paik and Lee33).

Constitutive equations describe the high-rate elasto-viscoplastic large deflection of thick circular plates. All the viscous damping, in-plane rotary and inertia terms are taken into account through the first-order shear deformation theory (FSDT). Geometrical and material non-linearities will be considered by the complete von Kármán system, and the non-linear mixed hardening rule will be coupled with a physically based (PB) viscoplastic model. Moreover, evaluation of metallurgical effects on the progress of ductile material damage and yield surface is regarded through a porosity parameter depicting void nucleation, growth and interaction.

In addition, cutting-plane algorithm and a semi-implicit integration for the RM technique are employed to approximate the required updating parameters, which must satisfy the plastic consistency of yield equation at each time increment.

Concerns of non-linearities persuade the designation of an efficient methodology to obtain unknown displacements, uniquely, with desirable accuracy and computational cost as well as numerical stabilities.

For this purpose, a pseudo-spectral collocation methodology will be accomplished on the basis of Chebyshev polynomials (section ‘Solution methodology (pseudo-spectral collocation method)’). Capability of the method has been examined to solve dynamic von Kármán equations for elastic structural problems (e.g. studies by Sharma et al.,34 Upadhyay et al.35 and Yosibash et al.36,37). Nevertheless, there are several important computational aspects that encourage one to adopt this method for present work:
However the weak form implementations of the differential equations (e.g. FEMs) cause to transform differential equations into sparse matrices, conveniently. Moreover, the low-order FEMs (h- or r-refinements) can be implemented easily, independent of Fourier’s or the Chebyshev’s convergence theory. Nevertheless, because of a non-zero polynomial of low degree for each basis function, they have some disadvantages of low accuracies for a specific degree of freedom N, in the many smooth multidimensional problems. However, spectral or pseudo-spectral collocation methods generate full matrix equations, but if a fast iterative matrix solver is applied by high-order basis functions, it can result in higher accuracy than the FEM and finite difference method for a given number of N.38
Chebyshev’s pseudo-spectral methods have exponential (spectral) convergence rate methods as well as high-order FEMs (p-refinement; e.g. Canuto et al.39 and Karniadakis and Sherwin40). This property makes them powerful over conventional finite element and finite difference schemes. Other advantages of collocation methods are eliminating dispersive errors and efficiency in numerical calculus.41 If the order of finite element increases, ill-conditioning problems will probably appear. Practically, the technology of spectral methods may be an appropriate tool to implement appropriate high-order finite elements. In reality, it can be said that for sixth-order or higher, they result in approximately the same accuracy with spectral methods. Moreover, when spatial coordinates are applied by the discrete Fourier transform (fast Fourier transform (FFT)), it makes collocation algorithm faster than higher FEMs, from O(N2) to O(NlogN) operations.42
Using these methods, collocation equations are simplified by discrete orthogonality and matrix representation of derivatives.42 Since, in the pseudo-spectral method, differentiation scheme does not involve any approximation of the spatial derivatives, fewer grid points are required to achieve computational accuracy. So, accurate spatial differentiation can minimize computer memory as compared to the finite difference method and FEM (e.g. studies by Boyd38 and Fornberg41). Consequently, it enables us to apply this method effectively for complex modelling, which may be even same as a simple one in size.
Treatment of non-linear terms is not the main challenge. Each grid point can be advanced independently of the others. Normally, implementation of boundary conditions is easy without special treatment of boundary points.

In addition, techniques of Houbolt time marching and quadratic extrapolation will be utilized to discrete temporal parts and to linearize non-linear terms of multiplied coefficients, respectively. In order to avoid any extra calculations, to increase programmability and to arrive at the stabilize solution easily, we try to evaluate components of the differential equations by means of matrix operations. In order to eliminate any weak blow-ups while arriving at the solution, some precautions are adopted.

Some of the challenges involved in the modelling are discussed. Influences of plate thickness and other parameters on the behaviour of the plate are considered with particular focus on the centre deflections, effective plastic strain and stress (dynamic flow stress), temperature sensitivity and time historical distributions of stresses in plate. The results of modelling are verified with the existing experimental data and finite element simulations from the literature, where excellent correlations are observed.

sec.title: Theoretical framework
sec.p: A circular plate with radius R, thickness h, mass density ρ and structural viscous damping cd that has been subjected to impulsive loading pz(t) distributed uniformly over the surface of plate is used.
It is noteworthy to mention that for convenience in displaying tensor operations and functions, both indicial and engineering notation have been used in this article.

sec.title: Kinematics formulation (incremental approach)
sec.p: Because of the dependency of actual stress on the path and loading history at the plastic regime, it is most reasonable to express the kinematic relations in the incremental formulations (e.g. Paik and Lee33 and Neto et al.43). At first, tensorial forms of the following increments of strains and curvatures are identified as

where prefix Δ indicates an increment for all variables and superscript ‘T’ implies transpose of tensors. In addition, ϵz, ϵz,e and ϵz,p represent total strain, elastic strain and plastic strain at plane z (distance z from mid-plane), respectively. For example, the increments of total strains can be written as follows
where
According to the FSDT, including complete von Kármán large deflection non-linearity, relationships between the incremental total strains and displacements in mid-plane will be expressed as

where ′ indicates ∂(⋯)/∂r, and u0, v0 and w0 are radial, circumferential and transverse displacements corresponding to coordinates r, θ and z, respectively. ψr and ψθ are the rotations of the transverse normal about the r and θ axes, respectively. Δεrr0 and Δεθθ0 are incremental total in-plane radial and circumferential strain, respectively, and Δεrθ0, Δεrz0 and Δεθz0 are shear strain increments for the three directions. Likewise, incremental total out-of-plane curvatures (Δχrr0 and Δχθθ0) with incremental total mid-plane twist, Δχrθ0, are given by
Stress fields are considered as vector forms as in the following
where generalized stresses, including membrane forces, shear forces and bending moments per unit edge length, are expressed by tensors N, Q and M, respectively, as

sec.title: Incremental equilibrium equation
sec.p: At first, according to the non-linear plate model,44 and taking into account viscous damping terms of the plane and rotational inertias, axi-symmetric large deflection equations of the circular plate can be extracted using the principle of virtual work. Afterwards, corresponding incremental form of this set of motion is derived as follows
where superscript ″ implies to ∂2(⋯)/∂r2, and

sec.p: Increments of elastic generalized stresses can be calculated as a tensorial form using the Hook’s law

where D denotes the elastic stiffness matrix that is taken by either Dext as the extensional (in-plane) elastic stiffness matrix or Dfle as the flexural (out-of-plane) elastic stiffness matrix. Therefore, we can write
Holding additional strain decomposition (total strain increment minus plastic strain increment gives elastic strain), equation (7) becomes
where

where E and υ are Young’s modulus and Poisson’s ratio, respectively. Substituting equation (8) into equation (5) leads to transformation of differential equations from stress states into displacement states with incremental expressions in terms of plastic strain and plastic curvatures indicated in Appendix 1.

sec.title: Modified Iliushin’s yield function and mixed hardening rule
sec.p: With reference to Iliushin’s yield criterion, all the plate layers yield simultaneously when stress state reaches the yield surface. In this case, it is obvious that stresses are not monitored in notional layers. In other words, in the non-layer approach, material non-linearity cannot be adopted in the entire cross section. This is, of course, a shortcoming for the physics of yielding, but the advantage is that it can avoid numerical integrating stresses through the thickness. Therefore, yield criterion formulation can be expressed in terms of generalized stresses instead of stress space.

According to real layer yielding mechanism, development of a plastic curvature is observed progressively from the outer layer of the plate. Material non-linearity in the cross section appears just after the yielding point. In order to get a closer insight into this phenomenon, particularly when the bending moments significantly affect the deformation, Crisfield45 proposed a plastic curvature parameter α as follows
where
Sine, x¯p lies in the interval 0≤x¯p≤∞, then we have 2/3≤α≤1.

Parameter α should be multiplied in uniaxial plastic moment M0, so that αM0 determines the moment capacity during yielding procedure. Therefore, this elastic–plastic scheme guarantees to avoid suddenly being completely plastic in the cross section. On the other hand, similar to the study by Yosibash et al.,36 shear forces and Bauschinger effect can be monitored in the yield function. Consequently, the Iliushin’s yield criterion is modified to simultaneously consider all the main parameters covering material non-linearities in both radial and thickness directions as follows
where

where M0=σy0h2/4,N0=σy0h. In addition, superscript * denotes generalized forms of back-stresses (representing the kinematic hardening parameters), and also, σy0 and ϒ(K) indicate the initial yield stress and material isotropic parameter, respectively, as
and

where, K is an isotropic hardening function in terms of effective plastic strain, ε¯p, proposed by Ishikawa47 for large strains, and constants K0 and b0 determine a saturated value of K and the rate at which this saturation is achieved. While plastic deformations in the structures are developed, the curvature across the thickness progresses from the outer fibres. In this case, the material shows a non-linear model upon the outer fibres start yielding.

On the other hand, to take into account the metallurgical effects on the fracture behaviour of ductile materials, a porosity parameter, ζ, can be applied. Introducing this parameter, which was addressed at first by Gurson,48 leads to transformation of the yield surface by incorporating the void nucleation, growth and interaction. Later on, a modified increment of that was introduced49 as

where iandj=r,θ and k1, k2 and k3 are the material constants, and the first two terms of equation denote nucleation due to cracking of the second-phase particles and debonding of the second-phase particles from the matrix material. Moreover, the third term presents growth of voids. Material constant n0 has been determined by Perzyna.50 One evolution form of back-stress has been expressed by Armstrong and Frederick51
in which, c1 and c2 are material parameters to be determined by experiments or can be evaluated by two constants β1 and β2, similar to that of Bieniek and Funaro52
The incremental effective plastic strain and curvature (hardening internal variables) can be expressed using the Einstein summation convention as follows
Moreover, by integrating the back-stress increments over the thickness of the plate, the generalized kinematic hardening parameters are extracted
where
and
Incremental plastic strains and curvatures are determined using the Prandtl–Reuss associated flow rule

where Δλ is as a proportional multiplier for plastic strain rate. In addition, vectors fn,fq and fm indicate the derivatives of the yield function ℱ with respect to the membrane, shear and bending moment stresses, consecutively as
The values of above vectors can be derived using equations (10) and (14) as written in Appendix 2. Relations (17) and (19) are combined to result as
Here, ‘:’ is double contraction (double dot product) of two second-order tensors. Therefore, the increment hardening parameters of resultant back-stress can be rewritten as follows

sec.title: Viscoplasticity model
sec.p: To take into account the high-rate effects and irreversible deformation of a material under pulse loading, the viscoplasticity formulations can be appropriate for time-dependent plasticity. They may be mostly correlated with the effective plastic strain rate, which is specified by means of a particular constitutive equation. It can be assured by including combined non-linear isotropic and kinematic hardening laws in the following form
The above relation can be rewritten by a function Π as a non-linear equation versus Δε¯p
to solve with the iterative Newton’s method
Here, we can write
and

According to the yield function, it is obvious that the constitutive equation Ψ is a function of variables ℱ¯ and K Then, combining equations (25) to (28) leads to derivation of a differential of the effective plastic strain increment as follows

On the other hand, substituting equation (19) and equation (21) into equation (14) and considering the point that the maximum of plastic normal strain caused by bending moment occurs at z=h/2, the following is obtained

sec.title: RM algorithm
sec.p: In the multidimensional boundary-valued problems of plasticity, an efficient numerical recessive technique has been developed, which is known as the RM algorithm.43 For constitutive equations in the rate form of plastic deformations, this procedure as a backward Euler integration algorithm calls for the determination of quantities at the time step (s+1) using information at back step (s). Superscript (s+1) corresponds to the forward load step (time-marching step). This algorithm can be used to obtain the stresses (s+1)Σ determining the current stresses (s)Σ and elastic increment of stresses as
Equations (6) and (8), result in
so that the elastic trial stresses indicated by Σ(s+1)tr and plastic corrector Σ(s+1)co can be derived as
Therefore equation (32) is takes the following form

In fact, the stresses are then updated with the plastic corrector to bring the stresses back onto the subsequent yield surface at time increment (s+1). The elastic trial stresses Σ(s+1)tr are evaluated by having trial stresses at the back step Σ(s)tr and elastic trial stresses increment ΔΣtr chosen for total strain increments Δϵ0, which again takes the updated stresses outside of the yield surface. Consequently equation (33a) can be rewritten as
or in detailed form as

The total strain increments Δϵ0 are calculated by a solution strategy that is introduced afterwards in section ‘Solution methodology (pseudo-spectral collocation method)’. The plastic correction terms Σ(s+1)co are always directed towards the centre of the yield surface as
and using equations (19) to (21), we can rewrite equation (37) as follows
where
or

Hence, laying the stresses on the subsequent yield surfaces assures the consistency of the increments at forward steps with the flow and hardening rules. Similar procedure should be applied to account for the updated variables traced between steps (s) and (s+1). For instance, the back-stress is updated using equations (22) and (23) as
Accordingly, the new stresses given by equation (34) can be incorporated into the updated yield function (12a), which is rewritten finally for the step (s+1) as follows
where

ℱ¯(s+1)tr and ℱ¯(s+1)co are introduced as the trial and the plastic correction yield surface, respectively. They can be calculated with the same formulation of equation (12b) to evaluate F¯ but have two differences. First, to evaluate ℱ¯(s+1)tr and ℱ¯(s+1)co, stresses Σ in equations (12b) – (12e) are substituted with Σ(s+1)tr and Σ(s+1)co, respectively, and second, the back-stress tensor Σ* should be evaluated just at time step (s) for ℱ¯(s+1)tr, whereas they are vanished in ℱ¯(s+1)co. In addition, the remained function ℱ¯(s+1)pd interpreted as a plastic drift of yield surface denoted here by superscript ‘pd’. It can be evaluated in the following form
With equation (37), one can obtain
where
and Md=σ¯dh2/4, Nd=σ¯dh. In addition, we can rewrite
Utilizing equations (40) to (43) gives the following derivatives to incorporate into equation (29)

where I is identity matrix. Although, corresponding to equations in this section, ℱ¯tr,ftr and ε¯p need to be updated at any iteration for a fully implicit integration, often with complex plasticity hardening laws, this may be challenging and a numerical technique is required. Therefore, applying a semi-implicit integration technique can relatively decrease complexity for this semi-analytical approach. For this purpose, the cutting-plane algorithm may be a beneficial iterative solution for the RM scheme, employing a linear approximation to numerically evaluate the plastic consistency of yield function (see more details in Neto et al.43). Accordingly, Δ(k)(s+1)ε¯p indicates the effective plastic strain increment due to the (s+1) th load increment at the (k) th internal iterations referring to counter of cutting planes. Whenever variables reach terminal values at the end of load increment, the subscript k becomes kt. In fact, Newton’s method can be applied likewise to integrate implicitly the effective plastic strain increment written at the end of the time increment (s), ensuring that drift from the yield surface does not happen. This task may be done by means of an explicit update of the normal f and the internal variables, such as the isotropic and kinematic hardening at time step (s), whereas it should carry out to the full implicit scheme at the time step (s+1). The value of d(k)(s+1)Δε¯p is computed taking into account equations (29), (44) and (45) and applying an appropriate function Ψ, representing viscoplastic behaviour of material. Here, it is suggested that the PB viscoplastic model introduced by Nemat-Nasser and Guo53 be utilized (see more details in Appendix 3). Moreover, it is remarkable to point out that effective plastic strain increment is considered as Δ(k)(s+1)ε¯p, but other expressions are evaluated at the back step time (s). Thus, starting from initial condition of a problem, a sequence of the following states is generated as
The imposed pulse pressure, where negative phase of the blast pulse is included, can be presented by modified Friedlander exponential decay equation (Gupta et al.54) as

where pm, τ and a are the over-pressure peaks for pulse distributed over the surface, time duration of the pulse (the time related to pressure drop from maximum value to third of it) and a non-dimensional parameter corresponding to pulse shape, respectively. They are related to weight and style of blast material distribution chosen arbitrarily to be proportionate to the comparable data. Thus, the pressure pulse increment associated with the time increment Δt~ is

where time increment Δt~ is taken as Δt for times that elastic state is only running (i.e. implied by E.S) or Δt* as a sub-incremental time step associated with internal iteration (k), for times after the instance that plastic deformation state has started (i.e. implied by P.S).

sec.title: Solution methodology (pseudo-spectral collocation method)
sec.p: At first, for mathematical convenience, by introducing the dimensionless radial coordinates ξ=r/R, the domain of a circular plate can be mapped to interval 0≤ξ≤1. It is assumed that the amplitude of general accumulated deflection function Φ(ξ) and plastic strains matrix ϵ0,p at the end of (s+1) th load increment step are evaluated by
where
Both functions ψ(kt)(s)1 and Δ(k)(s+1)ψ1 can be approximated by a finite degree series of shifted Chebyshev’s polynomials associated with their load increment steps
assumed to be matrix forms as follows
where
We can also write

The coefficients AΔψ1(s+1,k)i are unknown and must be obtained later for the time step (s+1) by the known coefficients Aψ1(s,kt)j that have been obtained at the time step (s). Moreover, taking into account the relation (85) (see Appendix 3), coefficients AΔϵ0,p(s+1,k)i can be calculated later by the non-linear functions in terms of the coefficients Aψ1(s,kt)j and AΔΦ(s+1,k−1)i. The spatial derivatives of the above general functions can be approximated, for example, as

where matrix D^β has been defined in the study by Gulsu et al.56 Accordingly, we can write

According to the incremental governing equations in Appendix 1, all the spatial non-linearities may have come because the means of two or more products of the typical arbitrary deflection functions in the general forms: gμ or gμ℘ϱ is given by

and ϱ or μ=1,…,4. Since, corresponding to equation (49) and (60), Chebyshev polynomials are multiplied together, in order to eliminate these non-linearities in gμ and gμ℘℘ϱ, it is appropriate to transform the product forms of Chebyshev polynomials into the addition forms. This task is illustrated here by defining, at first, some variables in Appendix 4. Then, by using a little algebraic manipulation, expressions of gμ and gμ℘ϱ can be rewritten in a compendious manner over the coefficients of Chebyshev polynomials as follows
where symbol ‘″’implies that each coefficient with index equal to zero (α¯a=β¯b=γ¯c=0) must be multiplied by 0.5. Equations (61) and (62) can be rewritten as
in which, the following tensors of coefficients are defined at the compact forms through the algebraic operations of series, as
and

Tensors ÂΔψ1(s+1,k)α¯1(λΔψ1) and Âψ1(s,kt)β¯1(λψ1) are the vectors of size (1×Lμ) and (1×Hω), respectively, and the square matrices ÂΔψa(s+1,k)α¯a(λΔψa), Âψb(s,kt)β¯b(λψb) and also, ÂΔψc(s+1,k)γ¯c(λΔψc) (2≤a,b≤4 and 1≤c≤4) are the vectors of size (Lμ+1)×(Lμ+1),(Hω+1)×(Hω+1) and (Hω+1)×(Hω+1), respectively. Their values can be calculated by associated indexes α¯a,β¯b and γ¯c. For instance, we can write

where ia=0,…,Lμ(a=1,…,4). In addition, if each component of the matrices contains a zero index (α¯a=0), it must be multiplied by 0.5. The other matrices can be calculated in a similar way, as mentioned above. Finally, combining equations (54) to (64) leads to obtaining the following compact relations
where

In the above previously mentioned equations, non-linear terms caused by multiplying components of ÂΔψa(s+1,k)α¯a,Âψb(s,kt)β¯b or ÂΔψc(s+1,k)γ¯c together can be made to disappear by the implementation of quadratic extrapolation scheme. This task is done by evaluating matrix components via three previous time steps. For illustration, it can be written in the following matrix form
where l=1,2,3, and Z(s+1ork) is the vector of quadratic extrapolation coefficients34,35 given in Table 1. Initial values to get continuity are

caption.p: Quadratic extrapolation and Houbolt coefficients.

sec.p: On the other hand, for discretization of temporal terms in the governing equation (Appendix 1), the implicit Houbolt57 time-marching method is applied to evaluate velocities and accelerations as the matrix forms
where
Houbolt coefficients Y(s+1or.k) and X(s+1ork) are evaluated during the initial steps listed in Table 1. Taking into account equations (80c) (in Appendix 1), equations (47) and (58) can be written as

Since symmetric conditions for loading profile and geometry imply that displacements and stresses are finite quantities, and also because slops must be equal to zero at the centre of circular plate, we have

Another point is that, pursuing the prior constitutive equations given by equations (2), (8), (19) to (21) and (48) to (52), all stress increments are non-linear functions in terms of Δψ1, and it can be assumed to express them by the Chebyshev series expansion as follows

Therefore, coefficients AΔΣ(s+1,k)N are the non-linear functions in terms of AΔψ1(s+1,k)N.. However, equation (75) may guarantee finite quantities for values of stresses, but this guarantee can be certified conclusively when the following extra conditions are taken into account as

Considerable point is that the force boundary conditions may create further virtual work, which must be regarded to give more convergences. Similarly, application of different force boundary conditions at the outer clamped edge of plate produces five equations as follows

All of Chebyshev vectors can be evaluated at the Chebyshev collocation points, ξi, (Chebyshev–Gauss–Lobatto points42) since according to a limited degree of relevant Chebyshev vectors, these points are only admissible to evaluate for i=0,1,2,…,N−2. Thus, the number of 5(N−1) required algebraic equations along with (5+5) boundary equations illustrated at equations (77) and (78) can be provided. So, a system containing 5(N+1) non-linear algebraic equations generated in terms of 5(N+1) unknown coefficients is expressed by a compact matrix form

where {DL} is a 5(N+1)×5(N+1) coefficient matrix, {𝒜} is a 5(N+1)×1 vector of unknown coefficients and {DNL} is an accumulate vector (5(N+1)×1) consisting of the non-linear terms, load increment, inertia terms and plastic strains terms that have been transferred to the right side and should be computed at each step of the marching variables. Therefore, this boundary value problem has transformed into an initial value problem and can be solved using the non-linear fixed-point iteration scheme via each internal iteration step. The above procedures are repeated corresponding to load increment advances. When the load increment is small in size, a more accurate solution may be expected.

sec.title: Preparations to computation
sec.p: Yosibash et al.36,37 characterized some challenges sufficiently to solve the dynamic von Kármán system while they applied Chebyshev pseudo-spectral collocation method for elastic rectangular thin plate. One inherent challenge was the initial-boundary incompatible condition at the domain’s corners. In addition, they demonstrated that numerical calculation of linear cross-derivative terms in the in-plane equations is a source for instability and can be made to disappear directly if the Legendre polynomials are applied instead of Chebyshev polynomials only for the linear terms.36 However, they were still dissatisfied because collocation treatment of the non-linear terms at the in-plane hyperbolic equations could generate aliasing phenomena. It is worth mentioning that aliasing as a non-linear source may produce ever-higher spatial frequencies, which cause numerical instability after a long time.37 Since the domain of interest has no corner, it does not suffer from mentioned incompatibility. Moreover, it is symmetric, and therefore, there is no linear cross-derivative term in the present in-plane equations. As mentioned earlier, implementation of non-linear terms is very easy in the pseudo-spectral collocation methods, but aliasing is a shortcoming for them, and we shall be relieved from it in our procedure. Fortunately, high frequencies can be removed by some filtering technologies, such as exponential filtering39 in the Legendre-collocation method only for the non-linear terms, the average filtering for the Chebyshev collocation method36 and, alternately, Digital Total Variation filtering58 applied in the study by Sarra,59 which improves the results and brings it very near the exact solution. In contrast, Upadhyay et al.35 did not report any interruption from the non-linear terms when they utilized the Chebyshev collocation method. Similarly, these noises were not threatening our investigations. Presumably, they could not be aggregated during the procedure because of being a short time for process. Hence, we can tolerate them only for small amplitudes to avoid any interruption.

Alternately, another poor instability might occasionally interrupt the solution and stop process. Although this source has not been characterized precisely here, it would suffice to say that it may be caused through numerical calculation of cutting-plane algorithms in the internal loops. Then, some precautions are adopted to preserve the stability region and reduce noises partially, such as modifying degree of truncated series besides adapting time increments and continually depending on the process steps.

Since, a high-intensity Friedlander exponential impulsive load is applied initially with larger over-pressure than elastic limit, the shakedown phenomenon cannot occur during the process. The infinitesimal time increments Δt and Δt* are chosen arbitrarily corresponding to the deformation states. The unknown coefficients are obtained at (s+1) steps. This procedure is repeated according to increase in steps, using predetermined coefficients of previous steps. Immediately after plastic deformation starts, related instant, t*, is recorded to start applying internal iteration (k) over internal sub-time interval Δt*. Prior to instant t*, all points are elastic and may be fluctuated with the presence of damper effects. Afterwards, some points stay in the elastic zone at a moment, so that they reach the plastic zone, and the plate deformation permanently takes a dome shape with little residual energy that may be a proof for any elastic spring back or a cause for the snap-type instability phenomena. It is obvious that inserting Δt* is a very vital factor, in particular, at the instant that the process continues to reach a fluctuating response with short amplitude and instabilities may interrupt procedure. In order to avoid this annoying matter, small variable time increments (down to Δt*≤1×10−7s) have to be taken in the simulations to obtain a better convergence. Three prescribed threshold tolerances (standard machine zeros) must be chosen to converge solution:

list-item.p:
ϵtol
: for fixed-point iteration solving algebraic system;

δ
~
tol
: for stopping the solution (calculating final time: tf*).

sec.p: These threshold tolerances are dependent on precision of the computing machine, which can be fixed several times by exploring through trial and error, for numerical outputs. To prevent any blow-up during each solving procedure, several degrees of Chebyshev approximating series are examined to determine an upper limit for the order of Chebyshev polynomial matrix represented by N+1. Computations can give accurate results just for this optimum degree depending on calculus errors and prescribed threshold tolerance. By enhancement of degree, results improve till adequate precision is reached, and more increase in degree causes generation of instability and does not converge into threshold tolerance (blow-up occurs).

sec.title: Calculating final time by plastic work
sec.p: The final time for the process must be fixed at the instant that all the displacement fields desist from movement, although, in practice, there is no exact rule to calculate at what instant these ceases happen. This is because components of translational and flexural displacements behave separately in three dimensions and fluctuation in the central region of the plate is much complex for consideration. It most likely seems that development of failure in thick plates follows from more complex schemes as compared to thin plates. In fact, determining failure localization requires more true studies for post-failure mechanism. Thus, if it is interesting to trace the behaviour of the plate only for the first failure mode (mode I, related to some researcher’s definitions1–7) in dynamic elasto-viscoplastic phase, then, it also may be practical to control the solution of the procedure by plastic work, in the following form
where plastic work is approximated by Gaussian quadrature integration

sec.title: Temperature sensitivity
sec.p: As a matter of fact, only a small fraction of plastic work is stored as dislocations and vacancies. This fraction drops from about 5% initially to 1% or 2% at high strains.53 In the absence of friction and inhomogeneous flow, the residual is released as heat through strain hardening, which is either dissipated to the environment or is stored to enhance temperature. Whenever the rate of generated heat is larger than the lost heat, temperature rises, in particular, at high strain rate situations. In viscoplastic materials, effective stress (flow stress) is dependent on temperature, and a continuous temperature rise reduces flow stress simultaneously during deformation. Assuming an adiabatic deformation (variable temperature), because of the short duration of loading, the temperature rise can be calculated as follows

where CV is the temperature-dependent heat capacity at the reference temperature Tr and β is the fraction of the plastic work converted to heat that is equal to 1 for large strains (i.e. ε¯p≥20%).53 Both CV and W¯dp are measured per unit original volume of specimen.

sec.title: Verifying the present collocation model by consequential outputs
sec.p: A conventional dimensionless impulsive parameter, I¯, is used by impulse, I, as

Here, it is appropriate to take a dimensionless slenderness ratio, S.R=σy0R2/Eh2, referring to a definition for stocky and slender plates. This study focuses on high-rate behaviour for moderately thick plates, and, the results are actually verified by empirical and numerical simulations performed in the study by Amini et al.27 with thickness h=1.02mm and initial kinetic energy Ek=1929J, which leads to attribute impulse I=18.96N.s. Of course, the part of the rim in Amini et al.’s27 study is neglected here and DH-36-steel fully clamped circular plates are considered by different diameters

Moreover, it is supposed that plates are exposed to a Friedlander exponential impulse in equations (46) and (47) with over-pressure peak; pm=1.103GPa, loading duration τ=15×10−6s and a=0.35. Moreover, deviations of this comparison will be illustrated with quantifying main parameters to distinguish between them.

The performance of steels is mostly dependent on structural characteristics. The mechanical properties of DH-36 steel as a body centred cubic (BCC) metal are strongly sensitive to high temperature and strain rate impurities. Since this steel possesses high toughness and strength (carbon content is about 0.14%) over various loading and temperature conditions, it provides good compatibility in many naval applications. Nemat-Nasser and Guo53 carefully investigated mechanical properties of DH-36 steel for a wide range of strain rates (0.001–8000/s) and temperatures (77–1000 K) and then proposed a PB model for its material viscoplasticity behaviour (see Appendix 3). In Table 2, mechanical properties for DH-36 steel plate have been summarized from experimental reports.19–21,27,47,53

caption.p: Mechanical properties of a DH-36 steel plate.

sec.p: In addition, physical parameters of viscoplasticity model for DH-36 steel proposed in Nemat-Nasser and Guo’s53 study are listed in Table 3.

caption.p: Physical parameters of the viscoplastic constitutive model for DH-36 steel.

sec.p: In Table 3, a0 is a free parameter, which is obtained from initial average dislocation (higher initial dislocation density represents smaller a0) and m1 is determined from experimental tests. In these calculations, time intervals and tolerances are chosen: Δt=1.0×10−6s, Δt*=1.0110−7s, ϵtol=1.0×10-5, δtol=1.0×10−4, δ~tol=1.0×10−3.

Similar to the conventional studies, in order to observe the displacement transition from the elastic zone into plastic zone, the centre point deflection can be considered as the time historical trend. In Figure 1, vertical deflections of the mid-plane on the centre point of a fully clamped DH-36 circular plate are plotted for different slenderness ratios. The results indicate good agreement as compared to the two FEM simulations.27

caption.p: The time history of mid-plane vertical deflection of centre point for various S.Rs; DH-36 steel plate (h=1.02mm).
FEM: finite element method; ALE: Arbitrary Lagrangian–Eulerian; L: Lagrangian; S.R: slenderness ratio.

sec.p: Present spectral Chebyshev collocation formulation predicts larger amounts of deflection for S.R=1.32 as compared to them. In addition, isothermal (constant temperature at reference temperature) treatment of constitutive equation for strain rate gives larger values than the adiabatic (variable temperature) treatment. Maximum of the transverse deflection is observed to be identical with the permanent mid-plane deflection at the centre point. Elastic vibration occurs after the instant that deflection reaches this peak value.

The complete advancement of plate deformation from elastic to plastic zone is predictable. This evolution can be viewed impressively by illustration of all deflection components in the overall points and times. To be brief, these results are not presented in this article, but assessment of translational velocity profiles demonstrate three substantial styles, which can be discussed here. At the initial stages, high-velocity deformations are observed at the plate edge, whereas deformations do not vary quickly at other places. Afterwards, they are being larger in direction towards the centre until the instance that maximum value of vertical deflection is obtained in mid-plane of centre point. In these times case, point in central area of plate behaves with elastic fluctuations. Moreover, counterintuitive deformations are still sensible even in times after impulse duration. Whenever a plate is moderately thick, plastic zone in the plate is less extended as compared to a thin plate (higher slenderness ratio), and as a matter of fact, elastic vibrations are sensible. This style of fluctuating changes relatively when the plate is thin, and the plate frequencies are increased with reduction in amplitudes.

Regarding this loading condition, similar to Amini et al.’s27 study, using viscous damping coefficient (according to studies by Stoffel et al.18–20) given in Table 2 and adopting a large number of degrees of freedom to discretize the plate, the elimination of the self-similarity phenomena can be assured at the resulting deformation responses.

The maximum vertical deflections in Figure 1 have been listed in Table 4 as well as the times at which that these maxima occur. Referring to results reveals that whenever S.R has larger values (thin plate), the maximum vertical deflections stand at higher ranges and lower times as compared to moderately thick plates (lower slenderness ratio).

caption.p: The maximum (Max.) vertical deflections of centre point for various slenderness ratios.

sec.p: A remarkable point observed by tracing the computations of strain components is the influence of edge force in creating negative circumferential strains close to the plate support. At the initial stages, radial strains are varied severely in places closer to support. Table 5 summarizes the calculation of the residual (final) amounts of principal strains on the mid-plane. The calculations include three directions, radial, circumferential and normal (thickness), in five radial positions.

caption.p: Principal strains on the mid-plane of plate at five radial positions for S.R=1.32 as compared to experimental data.27

sec.p: These computations are consistent with the centre point vertical deflection presented in Figure 1 and have considerable compatibilities, in particular, at points near the edge.

The rates of variation for radial and thickness strains fields are severely high at the central area. Nevertheless, circumferential strains have almost uniform distribution and little values in this region. Prediction of normal strain near the edge differs with the experimental result. This deviation has been caused by neglecting the rim of the plate in the present modelling.
The average of accumulated effective plastic strains within a 4mm distance from the centre is computed to verify the response of the plate in Figure 2.

caption.p: Average of accumulated effective plastic strains (ε¯p) versus time of deformation for different slenderness ratios.
FEM: finite element method; ALE: Arbitrary Lagrangian–Eulerian; L: Lagrangian; S.R: slenderness ratio.

sec.p: Whenever a plate becomes thinner, the effective plastic strain values are larger than thick plates, and this is because of more portion of plastic deformation with respect to thicker plates. In addition, results with and without temperature evolution express higher effective plastic strain as compared to cases regarding temperature rise. Referring to calculations, it is clarified that high strain-rates stand at interval 50 ≤t≤ 140 µs, approximately. high strain-rate. The average and maximum strain rates have been shown in Table 6.

caption.p: Comparison between isothermal and adiabatic analyses for average (Ave.) and maximum (Max.) statuses at first interval 300 μs and differences of dynamic effective stresses and temperatures.

sec.p: The isothermal and adiabatic variations of accumulated dynamic effective stresses of plate, which are averaged within a 4 mm distance from the centre for different slenderness ratios, have been illustrated as the time historical features during the formation as shown in Figure 3 and also in terms of effective plastic strain ranges, as shown in Figure 4.

caption.p: Average of accumulated dynamic effective stress versus time of deformation for different slenderness ratios.
S.R: slenderness ratio.
Variation of accumulated dynamic effective stress (σ·d) versus effective strain (ε¯p) for different S.Rs.
S.R: slenderness ratio.

sec.p: Although results do not show significant deviations for different values of slenderness ratios, those discrepancies imply relatively higher hardening in thin plates. Moreover, it is worthy to point out that adiabatic deformation of the plate leads to lower values of dynamic effective stresses with respect to isothermal behaviour. In fact, thermal softening of steel material causes these values to reduce significantly. As an important conclusion, most parts of the plastic work is converted to heat and only a little part, which is stored as elastic energy is devoted to evaluation of dislocations and other defects such as porosity parameter. Moreover, remaining energy may be consumed in edge reaction of die. If the mechanism of deformation is supposed to be adiabatic, generated heat increases the temperature of the specimen. In Figure 5, amounts of added temperature to prior time have been shown, graphically. The computations reveal that at time interval 50≤t≤150μs, the values of added temperatures are significant. The average and maximum values of strain rates, plastic works and dynamic effective stresses for the isothermal (constant temperature) and adiabatic (variable temperature) computations have been summarized in Table 6 at the first 300 μs along with the differences of dynamic effective stresses and temperatures.

caption.p: The temperature rise versus time of deformation for different S.Rs.
S.R: slenderness ratio.

sec.p: According to Table 6, hardening property of DH-steel plate is considerably affected by strain rate and temperature condition. For instance, at the first 300 μs, the ratios of average and maximum adiabatic dynamic effective stresses with respect to initial yield stress were about 2.49 and 2.76 for S.R=1.32, respectively. This deduction is implied extensively in experimental observations in the study of Nemat-Nasser and Guo.53 Consideration of temperature effects on the strain rate behaviour has been used by some researchers such as Johnson and Cook.60 In addition, Nemat-Nasser and Guo53 carried out uniaxial compression tests on the cylindrical samples with a size of 5 mm under strain rate 3000/s and observed temperature rise of 50.6 K at a true strain of 24%. Moreover, Chung et al.4 used applied FEM simulations by Abaqus to predict temperature rises of quadrangular stiffened plates. Although the results obtained from the present modelling are for circular DH-36 steel plate, comparison of temperature rise in the above-mentioned work indicates consistency of results despite the different geometry, material and amplitude of the imparted impulse.

Regarding related equations, the resultant stresses are dependent on the sign and values of strains and curvatures. Propagation of the resultant stresses has been illustrated as contour figures in Figures 6 to 11 for time interval 0–300 μs. In order to show the evolution of plastic zones, these are divided by the flow resultant stress (dynamic plastic membrane force Nd or the dynamic plastic bending moments Md). However, the main vibrating responses of plates are because of elastic deformation, but there are also other numerical calculus sources, which cause little fluctuations. We do not distinguish these sources distinctly, and we only point out that incremental solution of the constitutive equations along with the Chebyshev spectral treatments of differential equations have significant effects on this phenomena.

caption.p: Contour of dimensionless radial membrane forces: Nrr/Nd.
Contour of dimensionless circumferential membrane forces: Nθθ/Nd.
Contour of dimensionless radial bending moments: Mrr/Md.
Contour of dimensionless circumferential bending moments: Mθθ/Md.
Contour of dimensionless radial shear forces: Qrr/Nd.
Contour of dimensionless circumferential shear forces: Qθθ/Nd.

sec.p: According to Figure 6, amounts of radial membrane forces over the points of plate have almost uniform distribution at interval 50–80 μs. At points near the centre, these values are large and reduce along the radius from centre to edge. Corresponding to Figure 7, regime of variations for circumferential membrane force are not significant values during deformation of the plate. This observation comes from the fact that symmetrical geometry and loading do not affect the stress values in this direction significantly.

Contour of dimensionless radial bending moment has been plotted in the Figure 8. Relatively higher amounts of dimensionless values demonstrate that the radial bending moments have dominant rule on the plastic deformation of plate and assign more portions of yielding occurrence. Because the major deflection term is the transverse motion, the bending moments are significantly effective, in particular, at the clamped plate. The higher value of radial bending moments are observed at the time interval 80≤t≤120μs. Moreover, corresponding to Figure 5, most portion of temperature rise is obtained nearly in this interval.

The negative amounts for the radial bending moments are observed especially adjacent to the edges of the plate. This situation can be described by the principle of normality. Figure 9 displays a relatively smooth distribution of the circumferential bending moment, and slower rate of variations are similar with the circumferential membrane force.
According to Figure 10, many areas of the plate bear negative radial shear force with higher amounts at the near edge of the plate as compared to circumferential shear force in Figure 11.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: This incremental approach accompanied by admissible constitutive equations helps take into account the time historical mechanism of deformation for the moderately thick circular plate. All of the generalized stresses were regarded, simultaneously. This modelling provided good precision to obtain dynamic response of impulsively loaded plate by calculating a realistic strain rate, flow stress and evolution of generalized stresses. The results were comparable with experimental data. Moreover, this modelling seems to be more useful for thin plate when the rotational deflections in the von Kármán system are neglected. An advantage of this study is that the elasto-viscoplastic property of material was regarded simultaneously with contribution of a non-linear mixed hardening law. Application of PB viscoplastic model improved accuracies in the calculation of the centre deflection, plastic work, effective plastic strain and stress, temperature sensitivity and stress distributions over the surface.

Although using the full von Kármán system and the pseudo-spectral collocation method, we verified successfully high-rate dynamic elasto-viscoplastic behaviour of deformation (first failure mode) in the isotropic plate, but the present investigation confirmed that this methodology might be very useful to develop the solutions of high-rate dynamic elasto-viscoplastic behaviour, especially for complicated structures. Of course, it will be guaranteed by selecting appropriate base-functions and degree of truncation series and exploiting matrix operations. Therefore, we intend to develop the possibilities of modelling to scale other aspects, such as fracture predictions of deformation (other failure modes), in future.

app.p: Transformed incremental differential equations into displacement state is as follows

app.title: Appendix 3
app.p: The empirical viscoplastic constitutive equation proposed by Nemat-Nasser and Guo53 introduces dynamic yield stress σ¯d (effective stress) referred to as over-stress model and as a physical relation of effective plastic strain, ε¯p, effective plastic strain rate, ¯·εp and temperature, T as follows

and kb=1.38×10−23JK−1 is the Boltzmann constant (K denotes temperature degrees in Kelvin); G0 is the total energy of the short-range barrier to the motion of dislocations measured per atom; Tm is the melting temperature; ε·0 is a reference strain rate and d0, d1, σ¯0, n1, m1, p0, q0, and a0 are the material constants. Rearranging equation (81) gives ε¯p.)=Ψ for T≤Tc as follows

The non-linear mixed hardening rule can be coupled with the viscoplastic strain rate model when the state of stress reaches to the plastic limit. This task can be performed by replacing σy0 with the dynamic yield stress σ¯d, according to yield function (12a) and hardening parameter (13), so that
Substituting equation (84) into equation (83), and taking into account equation (13b), one can obtain
